YEs a little boring, but glad it helped you...
create descriptive mount points and mount them. look in them
Dont put them into fstab until you know which are which and have created descriptive mount points
sudo mkdir /media/ntfs-sde1                             sudo mount /dev/sde1 /media/ntfs-sde1
only temporary..
once you identify sde1 as lets say music sudo mkdir /media/music                             sudo mount /dev/sde1 /media/music
you can add it to fstab to have it mount on boot
Im just showing you how I do it
here is an example of my fstab..   http://paste.ubuntu.com/21299/
you cant edit your fstab until you know what partitions have what info/data// unless you have already done that
that should be all you need to know.. I need to spend some time with the wife...

/dev/sdb1  <  that needs to match your drive            /media/sdb1-ntfs-Data < that needs to match what you have on that drive    ntfs-3g users,auto,uid=1000,gid=100,umask=007 0 0                         the rest just leave alone
